Image: Virginia Sea Grant/Flickr (CC BY-ND 2.0) A new report has indicated some likely halts to FEMA’s disaster resilience policies and rules governing future rebuilding funds for public buildings located in flood zones. According to the New York Times, "Experts say the move, which has not been publicly announced, could endanger public safety and may be in violation of federal law."     A new report has indicated some likely halts to FEMA’s disaster resilience policies and rules governing future rebuilding funds for public buildings located in flood zones. According to the New York Times, "Experts say the move, which has not been publicly announced, could endanger public safety and may be in violation of federal law." This previously undisclosed mandate comes as the new Trump Administration’s temp appointee Cameron Hamilton, a critic of the agency’s response to post-Hurricane Helene flooding in North Carolina last year, has led to speculation about the direction it might now be taking in league with the President's other initiatives.
